etymology.description: semantic: 𣒚 (“bag with a bottom”) + phonetic: 石
etymology.interpretation: Originally a pictograph of a bottomed bag, later reanalyzed into a semantic element meaning “bag” plus a phonetic element. 石 provided the sound value historically, with the phonetic relationship clearer in Old Chinese than in modern Mandarin.

examples.chinese: 铁匠踏橐鼓风(鐵匠踏橐鼓風)。
examples.english: The blacksmith treads the bellows to stoke the fire.

examples.chinese: 他把药草装入皮橐(他把藥草裝入皮橐)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ yàocǎo zhuāng rù pí tuó.
examples.english: He put the herbs into a leather bag.

examples.chinese: 旅人解橐取钱(旅人解橐取錢)。
examples.english: The traveler opened his bag to take out money.
